Situation A. Analyzing Game Moves—Using Equations

Amber and her classmates want to make a game called the Game of Zero for the school family game night.

Before making up the rules for the Game of Zero, students experiment with various game moves using the following board.
Write an equation that represents the total value of the chips on the board after the move.

Possible answers:

  • remove 2 red chips;

(8 + -12) – –2 =

8 + -10 = – 2

  • add 2 black chips;

(8 + -12) + 2 =

10 + -12 = – 2

  • remove 1 red chip and add 1 black chip

(8 + -12) – –1 + 1 =

9 + -11 = – 2

Possible answers:

  • remove 4 red chips;

(8 + -12) – – 4 =

8 + -8 = 0

  • add 4 black chips;

(8 + -12) + 4 =

12 + –12 = 0

  • remove 1 red chip and add 3 black chips

(8 + -12) – –1 + 3 =

11 + –11 = 0

Possible answers:

  • remove 5 red chips and remove 5 black chips;

(8 + -12) – –5 – 5 =

3 + –7 =– 4

  • add 2 red chips and add 2 black chips;

(8 + -12) + –2 + 2 =

10 + –14 =– 4

  • remove 3 red chips and remove 3 black chips

(8 + -12) – –3 – 3 =

5 + –9 = – 4

Situation B. Amber’s Claim

Amber was working on the chip board and notices a pattern.

Amber’s Claim:

If you have the same number of black chips as red chips, the value is 0. For example, I can write this as +5 + –5 = 0.

  1. Do you agree with her reasoning? Explain.
Yes, because adding a number to its opposite will give you an overall change of zero.
2. Is it possible to represent this on a number line? Explain.
Start at +5. Then draw an arrow facing to the left that goes from 5 to 0, which would represent adding -5. Since that arrow ends at zero, it represents that the sum of the two numbers is zero.
Another possible answer by students might be showing that the absolute values are the same. Both numbers are the same distance from zero. So, if the numbers are combined, they would equal zero.
3. Describe three real life situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0.

Answers will vary. Possible answers: The temperature rises 20ºF during the day, then decreases 20ºF at night so the overall temperature change is 0ºF. You walk ½ a mile to school in the morning and then walk ½ a mile to go home in the afternoon, so your overall change in position is zero. You spent $10 on supplies to make bracelets and then earn $10 by selling them, so your overall profit is $0. I ride up 3 floors on an elevator, then I ride down 3 floors. I end up on the same floor that I started.

Situation C. Nadie Needs Help

Nadie’s Situation:

I was also analyzing moves on the chip board for the game. I have a chip board with 4 red chips. I need to subtract 2 black chips, but there are no black chips on the board. It is impossible to subtract 2 black chips. There are none on the board!

What can Nadie do to the chip board so that she can subtract 2 black chips? Explain your reasoning.

Situation D. The Game of Zero

After analyzing and representing moves on the chip board, Amber creates the Game of Zero.

Play the Game of Zero. Describe some winning strategies.

Equipment

  • black and red chips
  • chipboard
  • number cube
  • chipboard cards

Rules (play as teams or individuals)

  • A chipboard card is chosen randomly
  • All teams set-up a chipboard to match the chipboard card
  • Each team takes turns rolling a number cube. The team decides to add (red or black) or subtract (red or black) that number of chips from the board.
  • The team that gets their board down to zero first wins.

Students strategies will vary. Some students may begin by just subtracting chips until there are 6 or less chips of one color. Some students might think of adding chips while trying to get opposites on the board. Some students might use combinations of adding and subtracting based on the size of the number rolled.
